Description: Basic hreflang setup for sites with content in multiple languages. Each page has equivalent content in all supported locales.
Common Mistakes: Missing x-default | Self-referencing hreflang missing | Using relative URLs instead of absolute

Description: For sites targeting specific regions with localized content. Example: es-ES vs es-MX for Spain vs Mexico Spanish.
Locales: pt-BR, en-US, en-GB, es-ES, es-MX, fr-FR, fr-CA, zh-CN, zh-TW
Code Example: Use ISO 639-1 language code with ISO 3166-1 Alpha-2 country code. Example: es-MX for Mexican Spanish.
Common Mistakes: Mixing language-only and region codes inconsistently | Using non-standard codes

Description: When some pages exist only in certain languages. Only include hreflang for pages that actually exist in that language.
Code Example: Only add alternates for pages that exist. Don't point to 404s or auto-translated content.
Common Mistakes: Pointing hreflang to non-existent pages | Using machine translation without review

Description: For sites using ccTLDs like example.com.br and example.fr. Each domain serves a specific market.
Code Example: Use absolute URLs pointing to correct domain. Ensure all domains have reciprocal hreflang tags.
Common Mistakes: Forgetting reciprocal links | Canonical conflicts between domains

Description: Using subdomains like br.example.com for Brazilian Portuguese. Good for separate hosting/CDN per region.
Code Example: pt-BR: br.example.com | en-US: www.example.com | es: es.example.com
Common Mistakes: Inconsistent subdomain naming | Missing www subdomain hreflang

Description: Using paths like /pt-BR/ for locale prefix. Most common for Next.js apps with internationalized routing.
Code Example: pt-BR: /pt-BR/page | en-US: /en-US/page. Use routing.ts for Next.js intl.
Common Mistakes: Locale not in URL at all | Inconsistent path structure

Description: x-default tells search engines which version to show when no locale matches. Usually primary market or language detection page.
Common Mistakes: Missing x-default entirely | Pointing x-default to language selector instead of content

Description: For pages with dynamic content like user profiles or generated reports. May need selective indexing.
Code Example: Apply same hreflang rules. Consider noindex for user-specific content.
Common Mistakes: Indexing personalized content | Different hreflang per user session

Description: Blog archives or product lists with pagination. Each page needs proper hreflang pointing to equivalent page number.
Code Example: Page 2 in pt-BR links to page 2 in en-US, not page 1. Use consistent pagination params.
Common Mistakes: Linking paginated page to page 1 of other locale | Inconsistent pagination URLs

Description: When content only exists in one language. Don't add hreflang for missing translations.
Code Example: Only include hreflang for the language the content exists in. Don't fake translations.
Common Mistakes: Adding hreflang for non-existent translations | Auto-translating for hreflang
